Ed Exley.Action: Asks pertinent questions about the call (what's on the call sheet, description of the suspect), shows attention to detail and professional focus at the dispatch desk.
Maintains composure and humor despite dealing with an unusual and awkward case (Santa exposing himself decorated with tinsel), demonstrating maturity and confidence.
Raises a glass and offers a toast honoring his father's commitment to justice, showing respect and sincerity.
Engages politely with Dudley Smith, accepting a drink and listening thoughtfully.
Displays a reserved demeanor without overt friendly or warm gestures in interactions; mainly formal and duty-focused.
Firmly refuses to compromise ethics despite pressure to admit to questionable police practices.
Responds seriously and without evasion to Dudley's challenges on integrity.
Declares ambition for Detective Bureau despite skepticism from others.
Places first on the lieutenant's exam and expresses ambition for the Detective Bureau despite criticism.
Firmly refuses to compromise his ethical stance when asked if he would plant evidence, rig crime scenes, beat confessions, or shoot criminals in the back.
Dismisses Dudley's practical advice about the nature of detective work and the compromises it entails, showing confidence in his own methods.
Surveys the carousing rowdies calmly and does not get caught up in the groupthink or aggressive mood.
Raises his voice to break up a party that is getting out of control.
Reads a report and ignores the ongoing party, maintaining focus on official duties.
Shows concern and pursuit when he learns of inmates being attacked in the cell block.
Raises his voice to break up the party but is ignored; does not assert command effectively.
Reads a report carefully despite the distraction and maintains focus on his duties.
Checks on situation when informed about an incident; attempts to verify facts before reacting.
Not physically or verbally intervening in the violence occurring in the cell block, despite leadership position.
Orders Bud White to stop the violent beating to maintain order and insists on documenting the incident formally by taking names for his report.
Does not intervene physically to stop Bud's violence but attempts to assert authority through verbal commands and paperwork.
Is forcibly locked in a store room by Bud White after trying to stop the violence, showing persistence but possibly putting himself at odds with colleagues.
Orders Bud White to stop the violence, attempts to assert authority.
Attempts to take control by writing a report, showing procedural adherence.
Is physically overpowered and locked in a storeroom by Bud, losing immediate control of the situation.
Involuntarily leans back as Bud White passes by after being dismissed, showing some emotional reaction but no open support or confrontation.
Describes the situation to the Chief with detached, tactical language emphasizing public demand and political consequences rather than individual welfare.
Calls Bud White a mindless thug, ignoring Dudley's plea to see his value.
Volunteers to testify for the department and do what is right, showing commitment and integrity.
Bypasses Dudley and goes over his head to the Chief to get promoted quickly, showing ambition but ignoring camaraderie.
Suggests using Jack Vincennes as a corroborative witness, exhibiting resourcefulness and willingness to work collaboratively.
Accepts the Chief's decision knowing it will make him despised within the department.
States he is 'just doing my duty' despite expectations of payoff.
Clenches his fist in victory after encouragement to ace the grand jury.
Does not engage or respond to Jack's cynical insinuations about snitching for personal gain.
After being violently attacked by Bud White, Exley glares up and spits an insult, calling Bud 'just a thug' and dismissing him.
Sits alone late at night, patiently waiting for a call, showing dedication.
Pushes a patrolman aside to rush into a crime scene.
Arrives promptly and takes charge at a multiple homicide crime scene, pushing aside a patrolman to move quickly and take mental notes.
Shoves a rookie who is about to be sick out of the bloody locker and tells him not to get sick there.
Hurries past reporters and immediately asserts ownership of the case and willingness to take it despite Dudley's refusal.
Pushes for a police canvass investigating a potentially dangerous situation.
Reacts calmly and professionally to grim news received by forensics, sharing a look with Dudley.
Suggests canvassing for a purple Mercury linked to suspects; recalls earlier call about suspects and provides specific description.
Reacts thoughtfully to forensic update; exchanges look with Dudley indicating situational awareness.
Dives for cover when Flatnose grabs a gun and threatens him.
Receives help from Dudley after the staged gun scare, indicating some acknowledgment of team dynamics.
Dives for cover when Flatnose grabs the gun and threatens the officers, showing quick reaction and awareness.
Others do not react when Flatnose grabs the gun, highlighting Exley's greater situational awareness compared to his peers.
Keeps Bud informed about the ID of the body; shows a matter-of-fact attitude toward a tragic death, but also engages Bud in the situation.
Gently encourages Mrs. Lefferts to confirm the identity of her deceased daughter, showing patience and support as she struggles with the painful realization.
Calmly and patiently tries to get Mrs. Lefferts to identify the deceased, showing sensitivity and control in a difficult situation.
Does not realize Bud recognizes the deceased, missing a potential lead or insight in the moment.
Expresses disapproval of the ordered use of excessive force and implied killing ('He might as well have put a bounty on them.')
Watches others leave, wishes he could be part of the action
Steps up to take charge, confidently tells Redneck to leave it to them.
Steps up confidently and takes a calculated risk by accepting 50/50 odds on a difficult collar, demonstrating initiative and willingness to take responsibility.
Refuses a bribe from Patchett, an underworld figure, demonstrating integrity and adherence to his principles.
Dismisses criminal matters peripheral to the murder as irrelevant, showing a narrow focus that may lack broader empathy or concern.
Gathers information persistently by questioning Patchett about multiple people and connections, showing investigative skill and confidence.
Refuses a bribe or reward from Patchett, indicating ethical steadfastness and self-assuredness in his methods.
Stands silently during interrogation with no evident hostility or attempt to intimidate.
Nods to confirm his relationship with the D.A., backing up Jack's leverage with the Boxer.
Quietly supports an interrogation approach, demonstrating awareness of connections and procedural leverage.
Leans down to look in the window, calmly asserts command as ranking officer, urges cooperation.
Engages with potentially hostile criminals with measured calmness, lowering gun rather than escalating immediately.
Recognizes the LAPD two-way radio quickly and assesses the situation upon arriving at the scene.
Declares himself the ranking officer and attempts to organize the group to work as a team.
Does not escalate conflict by lowering his gun when meeting armed adversaries, showing control and judgment.
Grabs Carlisle's arm to prevent a shooting during the raid.
Tells Carlisle to be quiet during the tense moment.
Focused on memorizing details and determined to get confessions.
Offers cigarettes and matches to Ray Coates after unlocking his cuffs.
Engages Coates with casual, conversational remarks and references to boxing to establish rapport.
Mocks prison life and makes harsh remarks about potential consequences (e.g., 'get yourself a sissy'), using crude language.
Laughs off his own comments and appears to connect with Coates on a personal level regarding mutual acquaintance Larry.
Calmly and methodically questions Ray Coates, attempting to establish rapport and gather information after Coates is beaten up.
Shows patience and persistence despite Coates giving little to no response.
Uses details and analogies (boxing references) to connect with Coates and try to elicit a reaction.
Uses covert surveillance and aggressive questioning to intimidate Coates, employs racially charged insults and psychological pressure.
Stealthily obtains evidence by manipulating toggle switches to listen in on conversations without Coates noticing.
Uses interrogation techniques effectively by confronting Coates with contradictory statements and physical evidence like burned clothes and a hidden car.
Maintains control in a tense exchange, revealing knowledge and pressing Coates on incriminating details.
Successfully deduces and exposes attempts to destroy evidence, indicating good observational skills and intelligence.
Leans in close and asks Coates for information to feed the D.A.
Mentions the gas chamber to Coates and points out his guilt without prompting.
Observes Larry Fontaine weeping and prepares interrogation strategy.
Confronts Fontaine with Coates' betrayal and pressures him to talk, offering life-saving potential.
Explicitly tells Fontaine he faces death if he does not talk, using fear as motivation.
Uses psychological pressure and subtle manipulation during interrogation to try and get a suspect to talk.
Carefully prepares and prioritizes suspects for interrogation to maximize chances of getting useful information.
Takes a tactical break during interrogation to gather thoughts and reassess strategy.
Implies threatening consequences (gas chamber) to coerce confession, showing strategic understanding of suspects' fears.
Fails to immediately elicit a confession or cooperation from suspect despite repeated questioning.
Shows concern by focusing on whether the girl is still alive; encourages Jones to speak and implies a chance for redemption.
Presses suspects firmly and with suspicion (e.g., repeatedly asks who was hurt, questions Jones aggressively).
Expresses surprise at Fontaine’s emotional response, indicating some empathy or human reaction.
Presses aggressively for information about the girl's whereabouts, attempting to prevent Bud from using his weapon recklessly.
Attempts to follow Bud but is cut off by Dudley, showing restraint and respect for chain of command.
Persistently questions Jones to extract information about the girl's location despite no immediate answers.
Tries to intervene to de-escalate the situation when Bud is threatening Jones with a gun, showing some presence of mind.
Moves to follow Bud down the alley but is stopped by Dudley, indicating a willingness to follow protocol and chain of command rather than acting impulsively.
Confronts Bud White about using excessive force and questions the credibility of the situation with the ambulance attendant.
Gets steamed and confrontational towards Bud in front of other officers, focusing on procedural correctness rather than compassion.
Strides purposefully through the squad room and quickly locates the file he needs, reading it carefully for details.
Hurries over to Jack Vincennes' desk to check on his whereabouts, showing concern for a colleague.
Acts decisively and with Carlisle to check out a lead, carrying shotguns and moving through a potentially dangerous environment.
Commands suspects to freeze and acts decisively to neutralize threats, protecting others.
Is sanguine and numb after the violent encounter, shows no visible arrogance or bravado despite being hailed a hero.
Drops a handful of earth on the casket, has trouble getting the wet dirt off his hands during a funeral.
Insists on getting a chronology of events from a traumatized girl despite the nurse's refusal and apparent distress.
Feels and admits to internal doubt and unease about the case despite external accolades.
Has a private, candid moment of vulnerability with Dudley after receiving his medal.
Focuses on solving loose ends rather than celebrating his own success.
Receives the Medal of Valor from the Chief, recognized for a brilliant record and spectacular bravery.
Expresses intuitive doubt about the case and insists on unresolved loose ends despite forensic matches.
Uses the public moment of receiving an award to privately discuss concerns with Dudley, showing discretion and focus.
Shows some self-doubt and questions own feelings during a high-profile recognition moment.
Inquires thoroughly about rap sheets and criminal records, showing commitment to facts.
Questions Park Ranger genuinely to find the truth behind the shotgun firing report.
Reviews rap sheets carefully and questions inconsistencies in the case details.
Follows up with the park ranger to clarify conflicting information about the shooting report.
Gives a respectful and gentle approach to Mrs. Lefferts despite her distress, wanting to ask questions sincerely.
Cuts off Mrs. Lefferts running to the front door to prevent her from avoiding conversation, showing determination but possibly intrusiveness.
Shows concern and commitment to the case by following up on possible overlooked clues, demonstrating diligence rather than warmth.
Maintains professional composure entering the forensics lab, asks for details about the case, showing engagement and initiative.
Considers information given by Pinker and White critically, showing awareness of the challenges in the case.
Approaches Mrs. Lefferts calmly despite her fear and clearly states his intent to ask questions.
Notices and investigates the crawlspace entry after Mrs. Lefferts' mention of a thorough search and rodents, showing observational skills and persistence.
Demands that Jack Vincennes follow Bud White and threatens him with removal from the Badge of Honor if he refuses.
Requests an I.D. ASAP and insists on exclusive communication, demonstrating urgency and control.
Demands immediate forensic ID and asserts control over information flow ('You talk only to me on this one').
Commands Jack Vincennes to follow Bud White under threat of removing him from 'Badge of Honor,' showing assertiveness and understanding of power dynamics.
Interrupts Jack's phone request abruptly, demonstrating confidence but potentially abrasive manner that could hinder cooperation.
Admits to making mistakes and expresses a sincere desire to do justice and solve the case right, engaging honestly with Jack despite their tense relationship.
Presses Jack with direct questions about a sensitive case, showing persistence but also a lack of tact or empathy.
Admits he might have made a mistake and seeks help from Jack.
Directly asks Jack a pointed question about the Nite Owl killings, showing focus and determination.
Explains the significance of 'Rollo Tomasi' to reveal his internal motivation and moral drive.
Expresses sincere desire to solve the case right, showing integrity and commitment.
Negotiates with Jack over the share of the collar, demonstrating practical negotiation skills.
Negotiates with Jack for a third of the collar, showing assertiveness and understanding of stakes.
Acknowledges that they can't make a case without Bud White, showing realistic assessment of situation.
Follows Jack cautiously and is ready with a gun near the window, showing alertness to potential danger.
Questions Jack about drawing a weapon, indicating awareness and cautiousness rather than reckless action.
Flashes his badge and orders criminal to sit down; asserts authority in confrontation with 'Lana' and Stompanato.
Grabs 'Lana's wrist' and tells her to shut up after she throws a drink at him.
Identifies the significance of movie star look-alike prostitutes and connects it to a criminal operation run by Pierce Patchett.
Takes initiative to investigate by suggesting to talk to Patchett and first confronting Stompanato at the restaurant.
Methodically divides responsibilities with Jack by covering the bar while Jack goes elsewhere, showing tactical awareness.
Approaches Stompanato directly, flashes his badge confidently, and orders compliance, demonstrating assertiveness and procedural knowledge.
When provoked by 'Lana,' remains in control and physically restrains her, indicating decisiveness and authority in a tense situation.
Asks 'What's Fleur-de-Lis?' indicating a gap in knowledge about criminal slang or details.
Grabs Lana's wrist and tells her to shut up after she throws a drink in his face.
Laughs together with Jack after realizing the woman is really Lana Turner.
Engages seriously and somewhat brusquely in questioning about Lynn Bracken and the situation, including calling women 'whores' using the term after Patchett uses it first.
Plans to meet Lynn Bracken personally and speaks with respect about her appearance and demeanor.
Uses a somewhat threatening tone indicating he will 'take down' Lynn or Patchett if no answers are given.
Acknowledges Lynn's knowledge of him and keeps the conversation civil and focused.
Responds promptly to radio call and communicates clearly about next steps.
Plans to meet up with colleagues after visiting Lynn Bracken, showing coordination.
Approaches Lynn Bracken directly, identifies himself confidently and uses knowledge about her to try to gain answers.
Avoids reacting emotionally or defensively when Lynn mentions personal info about him, indicating self-control.
Issues a clear but controlled threat to Lynn to get information, demonstrating assertiveness and skill in interrogation.
Smiles and engages with Lynn in a friendly, warm way, sharing a drink and playful conversation.
Leans in and kisses Lynn impulsively, showing openness and intimacy.
Keeps composure and responds confidently to Lynn's taunts, asserting 'Don't underestimate me, Miss Bracken.'
Loses control and reacts emotionally by stepping menacingly toward Lynn and initiating impulsive physical intimacy.
Engages in a candid, somewhat intimate conversation with Lynn, displaying humor and openness.
Questions Lynn about her relationship with Bud White with some suspicion, implying distrust.
Admits he does not hate White, showing sincerity in his feelings despite professional reservations.
Shakes his head to avoid further hearing Lynn's emotional explanations, showing a reluctance to engage with her feelings.
Engages in a candid conversation with Lynn, acknowledges her toughness, and shares a moment of intimacy (kisses her).
Internally admits he would use Lynn's secrets against her but does not verbalize it.
Admits internally that he would use information against someone, demonstrating self-awareness of his own tactics and strategic mindset.
Engages in a candid and direct conversation with Lynn, showing interpersonal skill and confidence.
Shows a softer, more personal side by sharing a moment of connection with Lynn (kissing her), indicating ability to build rapport.
Works with Jack on a private investigation to make amends for a past mistake.
Working collaboratively on a private investigation connected to a murder case, showing initiative beyond assigned duties.
Not involved in preventing Dudley's killing or warned Jack about potential danger.
Watches Dudley leave, appears scared and hesitant to engage with potentially dangerous or suspicious information.
Tries to appear thoughtful when Dudley asks about Rollo Tomasi, but internally is scared.
Engages Pinker in conversation to gather details about the investigation, showing professional courtesy.
Simplifies people to their involvement in the case, making a dry joke about 'not a good week for ex-cops.'
Immediately questions Pinker about the Vincennes case and efficiently processes forensic information.
Connects disparate details about dead ex-cops and suspects quickly to form preliminary hypotheses.
Is photographed in a compromising situation with Lynn, indicating potential vulnerability or involvement in complex situations.
Takes initiative to inquire persistently about missing police records despite the clerk's impatience.
Portrayed by Lynn as 'cold, calculating' and the opposite of someone warm.
Confronts Bud with facts despite personal danger, attempts to reason and stop violence.
Uses physical violence to defend himself, aggressively questions Bud.
Finds the critical photo linking Dudley Smith to Turner Meeks and Dick Stensland.
During a brutal attack, manages to disarm Bud and turn the situation in his favor by using Bud's own gun.
Calmly interrogates Bud despite being under physical assault, drawing out information about Dudley and the motive.
Keeps calm under attack; tries to reason with Bud instead of reacting violently.
Focuses on solving the mystery and gathering facts rather than personal motives or feelings.
Thinks quickly and remains conscious under physical assault, tries to prompt his attacker to think, helping to extract important information.
Demonstrates detailed knowledge of criminal connections and motives, connecting heroin trafficking and murders with clarity.
Relaxes slightly during a dangerous situation, which allows the attacker to gain the upper hand.
Advises Bud to stay smart, build a case, and play by the rules instead of resorting to violence.
Encourages Bud to assist him in a difficult situation, inviting cooperation with trust.
Engages in calm, rational discussion despite Bud's frustration and talk of killing suspects.
Recognizes that the shotguns were planted and asserts this insight confidently.
Connects Dudley to Pierce Patchett and understands the bigger angle Jack was investigating.
Advises Bud to stay smart, build a case, and play by the rules despite pressure to take violent action.
Suggests a strategic approach of visiting Patchett and running a good-cop-bad-cop routine.
Responds calmly to Bud's question about expecting problems, indicating measured awareness of danger.
Immediately tries to keep up with Bud when he draws his gun, stays alert and concerned.
Comments on Patchett's suicide note thoughtfully, showing concern to understand the truth.
Offers practical help by calling a contact in the Sheriff's department to check on Lynn Bracken's safety.
Orders to hold the beaten woman as Joan Smith and restricts access to protect her.
Makes a sarcastic remark about having a party with hot dogs and sauerkraut when demanding a favor.
Pushes aggressively for wiretapping and surveillance without evidence, relying on a hunch.
Takes charge of protecting a victim by ordering her to be held under a false name and restricting access to her.
Attempts to strong-arm District Attorney Ellis Loew into authorizing extensive surveillance measures based on a hunch, without solid evidence.
Nods to Bud to proceed with violence against Loew, does not intervene to stop it.
Refuses to protect Loew from Bud’s aggression, claims ignorance on how to stop it.
Confronts Loew with sharp insinuations and tries to maintain upper hand in conversation.
Directs Bud to initiate intimidation and violence against Loew, coordinating the interrogation.
Admits he doesn't know how to call off the attack on Loew when asked, showing some lack of control in critical moment.
Helps pull Loew back inside to safety despite Loew being bruised and bloodied.
Threatens Loew with a gun to ensure secrecy and compliance.
Suggests checking records and consulting Lynn, showing willingness to collaborate.
Approaches Lynn gently despite her swollen, puffy face, listens to her carefully, and offers sympathy by mentioning Bud's guilt.
Expresses a personal, somewhat vulnerable desire to see Lynn again after the ordeal, showing sincerity and a hopeful connection.
Offers Lynn his handkerchief as she starts to cry, showing kindness and concern.
Insists on pursuing the truth about Dudley Smith, indicating responsibility but no direct display of warmth in this context.
Suggests checking records and talking to Lynn to gather information systematically.
Directly confronts Lynn and tries to get her to share information about Dudley Smith, showing proactive investigative initiative.
Uses emotional intelligence by acknowledging Bud’s remorse and trying to connect with Lynn personally after a difficult conversation.
Displays some uncertainty when interpreting Lynn’s cryptic response about Bud’s feelings.
Responds calmly to a dangerous situation with Bud, does not panic or show aggression.
Attempts to leave the scene when hearing approaching cars, showing self-preservation but not hostility.
Accepts the firearm from Bud without complaint, cooperates silently in tense circumstances.
Sits quietly contemplating the situation before opening the door to meet Bud, showing calmness under pressure.
Recognizes the danger signs as cars arrive unseen, quickly attempts to leave.
Allows himself to be held back by Bud instead of forcing an escape, showing situational awareness and acceptance of circumstances.
Prepares for potential violence by arming himself with a .45 automatic when handed the weapon.
Fails to prevent himself and Bud from being ambushed due to lack of foresight or prior warning.
Expresses a sincere desire to measure up to his father.
Returns fire confidently during the ambush, participates actively in a dangerous shootout.
Jerks foot when kicked by enemies who believe he is dead meat, indicating resilience and alertness in a dire situation.
Looks over and smiles as Bud reloads the shotgun.
Responds coldly to Dudley's threat, referencing fallen officers without remorse.
Quickly reacts to attack by spinning and shooting, taking down all four men.
Reloads promptly after the gunfight, demonstrating preparedness.
Smiles at Bud reloading, showing calm confidence under pressure.
Manages to recover quickly after being pushed to the ground by Bud.
Engages in tense verbal exchange with Dudley, asking relevant questions.
Dives for Bud's shotgun to protect him from Dudley.
Blocks Dudley from talking to the arriving police, refusing to allow dishonest behavior.
Does not answer Dudley's question about rigging evidence or beating confessions, but glares, indicating disapproval.
Dives for Bud's shotgun during a deadly confrontation, then maintains control by not dropping the weapon when the police arrive, effectively managing a dangerous situation.
Steps ahead to block Dudley's way, refusing to allow Dudley to manipulate the situation despite the threat of it advancing his career.
Does not answer Dudley's leading questions about unethical police practices, maintaining a stern glare and silent resistance.
Drops the gun and raises his hands over his head after Dudley is shot.
Sits bloody and exhausted while facing Internal Affairs detectives, acknowledging he has a lot to explain.
Runs a handshake gauntlet and looks for Lynn in the crowd, approaches her.
Engages Lynn in a quiet, supportive conversation about her next steps and Bud's condition.
Maintains composure during an Internal Affairs interrogation, clearly stating 'That's it. That's the whole story.'
Gets promoted to Chief of Detectives and receives public recognition while remaining somewhat self-aware and ironic.
Engages in a brief but meaningful conversation with Lynn, showing emotional intelligence and awareness of ongoing personal struggles.
Offers his Medal of Valor to Bud, saying it will mean something if it's his; touches Bud's hand gently in a moment of shared pain.
Acknowledges Bud's actions were without regard for rank or glory, showing respect and sincerity.
Acknowledges Bud's contribution without concern for rank or glory, shares his Medal of Valor as a meaningful token, demonstrates emotional intelligence and respect.
Shows vulnerability by questioning if he could have been 'in the running,' reveals self-doubt about his career achievements under pressure.
